[[File:Violante e Gian Galeazzo Visconti.jpg|thumb|upright|210px|Violante Visconti with her brother, [[Gian Galeazzo Visconti|Gian Galeazzo]].]] '''Violante (Jolantha) Visconti''' (1354 - November 1386) was the second of three children of [[Galeazzo II Visconti]], [[Lord of Milan]] and [[Pavia]], and [[Bianca of Savoy]].<ref name="Medieval_Genealogy">{{cite web |url=http://fmg.ac/Projects/MedLands/MILAN.htm#Violantedied1386 |title=Milan |first=Charles |last=Cawley |date=16 December 2009 |work=Foundation for Medieval Genealogy (FMG) |publisher=FMG |location=Oak House, Vowchurch, Hereford, HR2 0RB, England |accessdate=20 March 2010}}</ref> Her father gave to her the provinces of [[Alba, Piedmont|Alba]], [[MondovÃ¬]], Kenites, [[Cherasco]] and [[Demonte]] as an inheritance.
As a 13-year-old, with the promise of a large dowry from her father, in addition to her territories, she was married to the third son of [[King Edward III of England]], [[Lionel of Antwerp, 1st Duke of Clarence]] in the church of Santa Maria Maggiore, predecessor of the [[Cathedral of Santa Maria Nascente]], Milan, on 28 May 1368.<ref name=" Leese ">{{cite book |last= Leese |first= T. Anna |title=Blood Royal: Issue of the kings and queens of medieval England, 1066-1399 : the Normans and Plantagenets |year=1996 |page=149 |location= Bowie, Md |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zQLjug_Pr9wC&lpg=PA149 |oclc= 35870708 }}</ref><ref name ="Tuchman"/> The wedding festivities were lavish and ostentatious.<ref name=Effinger>{{cite book |last=Effinger |first=J. R.|title=Women of the Romance countries |url=http://ia331319.us.archive.org/1/items/womenoftheromanc18642gut/18642-h/18642-h.htm |accessdate=3 April 2010 |series=Woman in all ages and in all countries |volume=Vol. 6 | year=1907 |publisher=G. Barrie |location=Philadelphia, PA |oclc=9128840 |chapter=Chapter VI |chapterurl=http://ia331319.us.archive.org/1/items/womenoftheromanc18642gut/18642-h/18642-h.htm#Chapter_VI }}</ref> The banquet, held outside, included 30 courses of meat and fish presented fully gilded. Between the courses gifts the guests were given gifts such as suits of armor, bolts of cloth, war horses, arms, and hunting dogs.<ref name ="Tuchman">{{cite book |last1=Tuchman, |first1=Barbara W. |authorlink1=Barbara W. Tuchman |title=[[A Distant Mirror|A Distant Mirror: The Calamitous 14th Century]] |edition=1st |year=1978 |month=August |publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]] |location=New York |isbn=9780394400266 |oclc=3870107 |pages=239â243, 254 }}</ref> Among the guests were [[Geoffrey Chaucer]],<ref name=Coulton>{{cite book |last1=Coulton |first1=G. G. (George Gordon) |authorlink1=G. G. Coulton |title=Chaucer and his England |url=http://www.archive.org/details/chaucerandhisen00coulgoog |archiveurl=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015068314585?urlappend=%3Bseq=76 |archivedate=February 7, 2006 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |year=1908 |publisher=[[Methuen Publishing|Methuen & co.]] |location=London |isbn=9781112086274 |oclc=287618468 |id={{ASIN|B005LXKDAS}} |pages=48â49 accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> [[Petrarch]],<ref name="Hollway-Calthrop">{{cite book |last=Hollway-Calthrop |first=Henry Calthrop |title=Petrarch: his life and times |year=1907 |pages=279â280 |location= New York |url=http://www.archive.org/details/petrarchhislifet00holl |oclc=263026782 |publisher=G.P. Putnam's Sons |accessdate=27 March 2010 }}</ref> [[Jean Froissart]] and [[John Hawkwood]].<ref name=Waters>{{cite book |last1=Waters |first1=Robert Edmond Chester |title=Genealogical memoirs of the extinct family of Chester of Chicheley their ancestors and descendants |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oGMBAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA304#v=onepage&q=Violante |archiveurl=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101073398685?urlappend=%3Bseq=348 |archivedate=December 2002 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |volume=1 |year=1878 |publisher=Robson & Sons |location=London, UK |isbn=9781146966900 |oclc=609150822 }}</ref> The marriage was short-lived. Lionel died in Alba on 17 October that year, just five months after the wedding. His death may have been due to food poisoning.<ref name="Mediaeval Combat Society">{{cite web |url=http://www.themcs.org/characters/Lionel%20Plantagenet.htm |title=Lionel Plantaganet |first=Graham |last=Field |date=30 June 2008 |publisher=[[Mediaeval Combat Society]] |location=Middlesex, England, UK |accessdate=25 October 2011 }}</ref> The Duchess of Clarence had no issue by the Duke.<ref name=" Leese "/>
On 2 August 1377, Violante's father negotiated a second marriage, to [[Secondotto, Marquess of Montferrat]]. Sixteen months later, on 16 December 1378, Secondotto was assassinated after a battle at Piacenza (or Asti).<ref name="Bertelli">{{cite book |last1= Bertelli |first1=Sergio |authorlink1= |last2=Cardini |first2=Franco |last3=Zorzi |first3=Elvira Garbero |last4=Acanfora |first4=Elisa |last5=Chesne |first5=Giuliana |last6=Griffo |first6=DaphinÃ© |last7=Fantoni |first7=Marcello |last8=Florescu |first8=Ileana |last9=Galli |first9=Daniela Mignani |title=The courts of the Italian Renaissance |year=1986 |publisher=Facts on File |location=New York, NY |oclc= 13792156 |page=58}}</ref> They had no issue.<ref name ="Tuchman"/>
On 18 April 1381, she married a third time to her cousin Ludovico Visconti, lord governor of [[Lodi, Lombardy|Lodi]] and [[Parma]]. He was the son of her paternal uncle [[BernabÃ² Visconti]] and his wife [[Beatrice Regina della Scala]]. They had a son, Giovanni Visconti, who was born after 1382.<ref name=" Maximilian1">[http://www.maximiliangenealogy.co.uk/maximilia/pafg44.htm#28805 Maximilian Genealogy Master Database 2000 , 19 November 2009], retrieved 3 April 2010</ref> [[Barbara Tuchman]] suggests that her brother may have killed her third husband.<ref name ="Tuchman"/>
She was a sister-in-law to [[Isabelle of Valois (1348-1372)|Isabelle of Valois]], the youngest daughter of King [[John II of France]]. As a niece of [[BernabÃ² Visconti]], she was cousin to [[Valentina Visconti, Queen of Cyprus]] and had cousins who married into Austrian and Bavarian nobility, including [[Viridis Visconti]], grandmother of [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|emperor Frederick III]] and [[Taddea Visconti]], mother of [[Isabeau of Bavaria]], of France, whose daughters [[Isabella of Valois]] and [[Catherine of Valois]] were both [[Queen consort|Queen consorts of England]].<ref name="Medieval_Genealogy2">{{cite web |url=http://fmg.ac/Projects/MedLands/CAPET.htm#_Toc154137016 |title=FRANCE CAPETIAN KINGS |first=Charles |last=Cawley |date=February 26, 2011 |work=Foundation for Medieval Genealogy (FMG) |publisher=FMG |location=Oak House, Vowchurch, Hereford, HR2 0RB, England |accessdate=August 13, 2011 }}</ref>
Violante died in Pavia in November 1386, at the age of 32.<ref name=" Maximilian2">[http://www.maximiliangenealogy.co.uk/maximilia/pafg44.htm#555 Maximilian Genealogy Master Database 2000, 19 November 2009], retrieved 3 April 2010</ref>
